longDescription:
Yangon (Rangoon), Myanmar (Burma) The Shwedagon Pagoda (Burmese: Shwedagon Zedi Daw, meaning "Great Dagon Pagoda") is the most sacred
                Buddhist site in Myanmar and one of the most magnificent religious monuments in the world. Rising
                99 meters (325 feet) above Singuttara Hill in Yangon, its gold-plated stupa can be seen from miles
                around, glittering brilliantly in the tropical sun. According to tradition, the pagoda enshrines
                relics of four Buddhas: the staff of Kakusandha, the water filter of Konagamana, a piece of robe
                of Kassapa, and eight hairs of Gautama Buddha given directly to two merchant brothers who met
                him shortly after his enlightenment.
name: Shwedagon Pagoda

description:
Explore temples, mountains, groves, and holy sites that have served as gateways between the human and divine realms
                across cultures and millennia. From ancient stone circles to living pilgrimage destinations, discover the places
                where heaven touches earth.

geography: Architectural structure; often positioned at cosmically significant locations; contains sanctum sanctorum and ceremonial chambers
history: archaeological evidence suggests the current structure was built by the Mon people between the 6th and 10th centuries CE. The pagoda has been enlarged and renovated countless times, with successive Burmese kings adding gold, jewels, and expanding the structure as acts of merit. Today, the main stupa is covered with over 8,000 solid gold plates and crowned with a diamond-studded spire containing 5,448 diamonds, 2,317 rubies, and one 76-carat diamond at its very top. c. 588 BCE (Traditional) Two merchants receive eight hairs from the Buddha and enshrine them 6th-10th Century CE Mon people build the pagoda; earliest historical evidence 1362 King Binnya U raises the stupa to 18 meters 1485 Queen Shinsawbu raises stupa to 40 meters; covers it in her weight in gold 1774 King Hsinbyushin raises it to current height of 99 meters 1871 King Mindon donates new hti (crown) studded with jewels 1920 Starting point of Burmese independence movement (Shoe Controversy) 1988 8888 Uprising demonstrations at the pagoda 2007 Saffron Revolution: monks march from Shwedagon
